questions.text: Identify the following image
questions.solution:
Pneumatosis intestinalis, indicates gas trapped within the bowel wall and can signal various underlying conditions. Key points include:

  1. Etiologies: The most concerning cause is intestinal ischemia, which can lead to bowel infarction. In neonates, the presence of intramural gas is often indicative of necrotizing enterocolitis.
  2. Imaging: While CT and plain radiography are standard for detecting this condition, ultrasound and MRI are valuable in pediatric patients to reduce radiation exposure.
  3. Appearance: Gas manifests as linear lucencies (submucosal) or rounded cystic collections (subserosal). The circular pattern of gas may suggest a benign process, while linear and bubbly patterns can indicate either benign or serious conditions.

Other options

B. Pneumoperitoneum - it includes air in the peritoneal cavity. x ray findings are gas under diaphragm.

C. Intestinal Obstruction - Multiple air fluid level seen. loops are dilated proximal to obstruction.

Diameter greater than 3 cm suggests small bowel obstruction,

greater than 6cm colon obstruction,

greater than 9 cm for caecum.

D. Intestinal atresia - X ray findings depend upon location of atresia.

Duodenal atresia - double bubble sign (1)

Jejunal atresia - Triple bubble sign. (2)

Key TAKEAWAY - In neonates, the presence of intramural gas is often indicative of necrotizing enterocolitis.

Gas manifests as linear lucencies (submucosal) or rounded cystic collections (subserosal).

questions.text: A patient presented with abdominal pain. On examination, there was guarding present in the abdomen. An Xray was done which is shown below. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Xray represents air under diaphragm, therefore it's a case of pneumoperitoneum. Exploratory laparotomy is done in these cases.

Other option explanation:

  1. Supportive care - it includes iv fluids, antibiotics, pain control measures
  2. Peritoneal lavage - It is not done nowadays.
  3. Iv fluids - it is included in supportive care not definitive management.

KEY TAKEAWAY - In cases of perforation, surgical repair is often necessary. Laparoscopy or laparotomy may be required, depending on the situation.

Provide supportive management, including intravenous fluids, electrolyte balance, and pain control.

questions.text: A patient presented with abdominal bloating and heaviness after meals, particularly after fatty meals. An ultrasound was done which is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Gallstones, or cholelithiasis, are solid particles that can form in the biliary system, primarily in the gallbladder. They affect about 10% of the population, with a higher prevalence in women (ratio of 2:1) and an increase in incidence with age.

Symptoms: The most common symptom is biliary colic, characterized by right upper quadrant or epigastric pain, often triggered by fatty meals. Other symptoms include:

  • Belching
  • Bloating
  • Flatulence
  • Heartburn
  • Nausea

Pain may radiate to the right shoulder, and a sign known as Collin's sign may be observed, where the patient experiences referred pain by placing their hand behind their back.

Diagnosis:

  1. Plain Radiograph: About 15-20% of gallstones are radiopaque and can be seen on X-rays. They may appear as laminated structures, showing a radiopaque outline with a lucent center.
  2. Ultrasound: The gold standard for detecting gallstones. Key features include:
    • A highly reflective echogenic focus in the gallbladder with posterior acoustic shadowing.
    • Gravity-dependent movement, noted as the "rolling stone sign".
  3. MRI:
    • T1-weighted images show pigmented stones as hyperintense and cholesterol stones as hypointense.
    • T2-weighted images may reveal a signal void or low signal surrounded by hyperintense bile.
    • MRCP (Magnetic Resonance Cholangiopancreatography) shows a signal void within the gallbladder indicating the presence of stones.

KEY TAKEAWAY - The gold standard for detecting gallstones is a highly reflective echogenic focus in the gallbladder with posterior acoustic shadowing while gallbladder polyp doesn't have post acoustic shadowing.

questions.text: A patient presented with abdominal bloating and heaviness after meals, particularly after fatty meals. An ultrasound was done which showed dilated intrahepatic biliary radicles. On doing blood tests, direct bilirubin was raised. What is the best investigation in diagnosing this condition?
questions.solution:
This case refers to the case of choledocholithiasis in view of presence of obstructive jaundice and the gold standard for it is MRCP.

MRCP (Magnetic Resonance Cholangiopancreatography):

  • Has become the gold standard for diagnosing choledocholithiasis.
  • Offers similar sensitivity (90-94%) and specificity (95-99%) without radiation or the risks associated with ERCP.
  • Filling defects in the biliary tree are noted on thin cross-sectional T2-weighted images.

Other option explanation:

A. CT scan:

  • Contrast-enhanced CT has moderate sensitivity (65-88%).
  • Important subtle signs include:
    • Target sign: Central rounded density (stone) with surrounding lower attenuating bile or mucosa.
    • Rim sign: Stone outlined by a thin rim of high density.
    • Crescent sign: Low attenuation crescent of bile eccentrically outlining a stone.

CT Cholangiography:

  • Using biliary excreted contrast agents, this method has high sensitivity (88-96%) and specificity (88-98%) for choledocholithiasis
  • However, it is limited by complication rates of contrast agents and is best suited for patients with normal liver function tests.

C. Ultrasound:

  • Typically, the first-line investigation for biliary issues.
  • Key findings include:
    • Visualization of stones as echogenic rounded foci (size can range from 2 to over 20 mm).
    • Shadowing may be less pronounced than with gallbladder stones
    • Dilatation of the bile duct (>6 mm, increasing by 1 mm per decade after age 60; >10 mm post-cholecystectomy) and dilated intrahepatic biliary tree raise suspicion of stones.

Endoscopic Ultrasound (EUS):

  • Offers very high sensitivity and specificity for detecting choledocholithiasis.

KEY TAKEAWAY - Choledocholithiasis refers to the presence of gallstones in the bile ducts, particularly the common hepatic and common bile ducts. The gold standard for its diagnosis is MRCP.

questions.text: A patient presented with severe abdominal pain. On doing blood tests, direct bilirubin was raised. He had a previous ultrasound showing gall stones. Which of the following is not a finding in USG?
questions.solution:
Increased bilirubin is suggestive of obstructive biliopathy. Obstructive biliopathy refers to block at a higher level (CHD).

Distal bile duct will be collapsed instead of dilated.

Other option explanation:

Choledocholithiasis refers to the presence of gallstones in the bile ducts, particularly the common hepatic and common bile ducts. These stones can come from gallbladder and associated cholecystitis with gallbladder wall edema therefore stone can be impacted in cystic duct

Diagnosis

  • Ultrasound:
    • Typically, the first-line investigation for biliary issues.
    • Key findings include:
      1. Visualization of stones as echogenic rounded foci
      2. Shadowing may be less pronounced than with gallbladder stones,
      3. Dilatation of the bile duct (>6 mm) and dilated intrahepatic biliary tree raise suspicion of stones.
    • Endoscopic Ultrasound (EUS):
      • Offers very high sensitivity and specificity for detecting choledocholithiasis.
    • CT Imaging:
      • Contrast-enhanced CT has moderate sensitivity
      • Important subtle signs include:
        1. Target sign: Central rounded density (stone) with surrounding lower attenuating bile or mucosa.
        2. Rim sign: Stone outlined by a thin rim of high density.
        3. Crescent sign: Low attenuation crescent of bile eccentrically outlining a stone.
      • CT Cholangiography:
        • Using biliary excreted contrast agents, this method has high sensitivity and specificity for choledocholithiasis.
        • However, it is limited by complication rates of contrast agents and is best suited for patients with normal liver function tests.
      • MRCP (Magnetic Resonance Cholangiopancreatography):
        • Has become the gold standard for diagnosing choledocholithiasis.
        • Offers similar sensitivity and specificity without radiation or the risks associated with ERCP.
      • Filling defects in the biliary tree are noted on thin cross-sectional T2-weighted images

KEY TAKEAWAY - Choledocholithiasis refers to the presence of gallstones in the bile ducts, particularly the common hepatic and common bile ducts.

MRCP has become the gold standard for diagnosing choledocholithiasis.

questions.text: A patient presented with fever and abdominal pain. No other symptom was present. He had a history of non-vegetarian diet. A CT scan was done which showed the following image. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Hydatid cysts are formed as a result of infection by Echinococcus tapeworm species and can occur in various body locations, most commonly the liver.

These cysts have three distinct components:

  1. Pericyst: A dense fibrous capsule formed by the host's immune response.
  2. Exocyst (laminated membrane): A semi-permeable, acellular membrane produced by the parasite.
  3. Endocyst: The inner germinal layer of the parasite, which produces daughter cysts containing Protoscolices (larval form).

Imaging Characteristics

  1. Plain Radiograph:
    • May show a curvilinear or ring-like calcific shadow over the liver, indicating calcification of the pericyst.
  2. Ultrasound:
    • Typically reveals a septated cyst with potential "daughter" cysts and echogenic material within.
    • Can display a double echogenic shadow due to the pericyst.
  3. CT Imaging:
    • Septa and daughter cysts may be visualized.
    • The "water-lily sign" indicates a cyst with a floating, undulating membrane due to a detached endocyst.
    • May show hyperdense internal septa with a spoke-wheel pattern.
    • Fluid density can vary based on the amount of proteinaceous debris.
  4. MRI:
    • T1-weighted: Displays mixed low signal intensity depending on proteinaceous debris content.
    • T2-weighted: Shows mixed high signal intensity, with clear visualization of septa and daughter cysts, particularly in single-shot T2 sequences.
    • T1 C+ (Gadolinium): Enhances the walls and septa,

Gharbi and WHO classification of hydatid disease

Other option explanation:

b. Hepatic abscess - peripheral rim enhancement seen. center will be hypodense compared to peripheral.

c. Hepatic metastasis - typically include hypoattenuation, peripheral enhancement, and varying size and number.

d. Hepatic hematoma - typically include a hyperattenuating mass within the liver, often with surrounding hypoattenuation.

KEY TAKEAWAY - Hydatid cyst appears as a fluid-density cyst, often with peripheral calcifications indicating a lack of active infection if completely circumferential.

"water-lily sign" indicates a cyst with a floating, undulating membrane due to a detached endocyst.

questions.text: A patient presented with abdominal pain radiation to back. On doing a CT scan, the following image was obtained. What scoring system is used in defining the severity of the disease?
questions.solution:
The modified CT severity index (MCTSI) classify the severity of acute pancreatitis into mild, moderate, and severe forms. The scoring system assesses pancreatic inflammation and necrosis, resulting in a score out of 10.

Other option explanation:

Glasglow scale - It is used to assess the level of consciousness in individuals

Fischer system - used to predict the risk of vasospasm following subarachnoid hemorrhage

CAD RADS - It is used in reporting the severity of coronary artery diseases.

KEY TAKEAWAY - Modified CTSI is used to classify the severity of acute pancreatitis into mild, moderate, and severe forms. The scoring system assesses pancreatic inflammation and necrosis.

questions.text: An infant presented with non-bilious vomiting. He was not able to breast feed. An Xray was done which is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Duodenal atresia is a congenital malformation of the duodenum that often requires prompt surgical correction in neonates. It is one of the most common causes of fetal bowel obstruction and is frequently associated with other conditions.

Associated Conditions

  • Down Syndrome: Approximately 30% of duodenal atresia cases are associated with Down syndrome, while around 3% of Down syndrome cases may present with duodenal atresia.
  • VACTERL Association: A cluster of congenital malformations.
  • Annular Pancreas: A condition where the pancreas encircles the duodenum, potentially leading to obstruction.

Clinical Presentation

Infants typically present shortly after birth with symptoms of duodenal obstruction, including:

  • Abdominal distension
  • Vomiting (bilious if the atresia is distal to the ampulla of Vater; non-bilious if proximal)
  • Absent bowel movements

In complete atresia, the duodenum ends blindly, resulting in no communication with the distal bowel, which is not aerated.

Radiographic Features

  1. Plain Radiograph:
    • The classic finding is the double bubble sign, which shows a gas-filled distended stomach and duodenum, with an absence of gas in the distal bowel.
  2. Barium Study:
    • barium can be administered via an orogastric or nasogastric tube under fluoroscopy to confirm obstruction.
  3. Ultrasound:
    • Can demonstrate a dilated stomach and duodenum, resembling the double bubble appearance.
    • This finding may not be detectable until the mid to late second trimester.
    • Polyhydramnios may also be observed as an ancillary feature.

Other options -

a. Intestinal hernia - A well-defined, low-attenuation mass that protrudes through a defect in the abdominal wall.

c. Intussusception - shows target sign. As the obstruction is more distal the vomiting is bilious.

Jejunal atresia - Triple bubble sign. Morphologically, type IIIB has Apple peel or Christmas tree deformity

KEY TAKEAWAY - In cases of duodenal atresia rule out

  • Down Syndrome
  • VACTERL Association
  • Annular Pancreas

questions.text: A patient came to OPD with right upper quadrant pain. On doing a CT scan, it was labelled as hepatocellular carcinoma and was under consideration whether to use LIRADS or not. In which of the following patients LIRADS cannot be used?
questions.solution: KEY TAKEAWAY: The Liver Imaging Reporting and Data System (LI-RADS) is a standardized classification system used for reporting imaging findings related to liver lesions, particularly in the context of diagnosing and staging hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC)

questions.text: An alcoholic patient presented with right upper quadrant pain and significant weight loss. On doing a CT scan, a focal liver lesion was seen which showed arterial phase hyperenhancement and early washout. Which of the following classification system is used for characterizing the lesion?
questions.solution:
The Liver Imaging Reporting and Data System (LI-RADS) is a standardized classification system used for reporting imaging findings related to liver lesions, particularly in the context of diagnosing and staging hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). It provides a consistent terminology and framework to improve communication among radiologists and clinicians.

Options explanation:

  1. PIRADS- PIRADS stands for Prostate Imaging Reporting and Data System.
  2. BIRADS- BIRADS stands for Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System.
  3. TIRADS- TIRADS stands for Thyroid Imaging Reporting and Data System.

KEY TAKEAWAY -

questions.text: A patient had a history of heartburn since 5 years, now he presented with difficulty in swallowing and regurgitation of food. On doing a CT scan, the following image was obtained. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Predisposing Factors

  • Alcohol and Smoking: Associated with both squamous cell carcinoma and adenocarcinoma.
  • Achalasia
  • Asbestosis
  • Celiac Disease
  • Ionizing Radiation
  • Caustic Stricture/Lye Stricture
  • Plummer-Vinson Syndrome
  • History of Oral or Pharyngeal Cancer
  • Human Papillomavirus (HPV0
  • Barrett Esophagus: A risk factor specifically for adenocarcinoma.
  • Obesity: Particularly linked to adenocarcinoma

KEY TAKEAWAY- GERD and Barretts esophagus are mainly associated with adenocarcinoma of esophagus.

questions.text: A patient presented with difficulty in eating and problems with digestion. He also had significant weight loss and was advised to undergo a CT scan. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Linitis plastica is a term used to describe the rigid and thickened appearance of the stomach wall, most commonly due to adenocarcinoma. This condition results from diffuse submucosal infiltration, leading to significant structural changes in the stomach.

Radiographic Features

Fluoroscopy

  • Barium Meal Examination:
    • The stomach shows inadequate distension due to increased wall rigidity, resulting in a narrow lumen.
    • The normal mucosal fold pattern is typically absent or appears distorted, thickened, or nodular.

CT Imaging

  • The stomach appears diffusely thickened with a small lumen.
  • Evaluation should include checking for lymph node involvement and signs of widespread metastatic disease.

KEY TAKEAWAY - LP is a type of adenocarcinoma, which is the most common form of stomach cancer. It spreads to the muscles of the stomach wall, making it thicker and more rigid

questions.text: A patient had a history of chronic constipation. Now he complained of bleeding per rectum. On doing a per rectal examination no significant abnormality was palpated. And was advised to undergo a CT scan which is shown below. What is the expected barium enema finding in this patient?
questions.solution:
Colorectal cancer (CRC) is the most common cancer of the gastrointestinal tract and one of the most frequently diagnosed malignancies in adults. A variety of predisposing factors have been identified, including:

Predisposing Factors

  • Diet: Low fiber intake and high fat and animal protein consumption.
  • Obesity: Particularly prevalent in men.
  • Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD):
    • Ulcerative Colitis
    • Crohn Disease: Especially in bypassed loops or near chronic fistulas.
  • Asbestos Exposure
  • Family History: History of benign or malignant colorectal tumors.
  • History of Other Cancers: Endometrial or breast cancer.
  • Pelvic Irradiation
  • Ureterosigmoidostomy
  • Colonic Adenoma

Clinical Presentation

Symptoms of CRC can be insidious, including:

  • Altered bowel habits (constipation and/or diarrhea)
  • Iron-deficiency anemia due to chronic occult blood loss

Acute manifestations may include:

  • Bowel obstruction
  • Intussusception
  • Rectal bleeding

Imaging Techniques

CT Imaging

  • Most colorectal cancers appear as soft tissue densities that narrow the bowel lumen. Ulceration may be observed in larger masses. Mucinous tumors can appear as low-density masses, with low-density lymph nodes. Psammomatous calcifications may be present in mucinous adenocarcinoma.

KEY TAKEAWAY:

  • Sawtooth appearance seen on Barium enema in Diverticulitis.
  • Rat tail appearance seen in achalasia on Barium swallow.
  • Apple core deformity seen on Barium enema in cancer.

questions.text: A patient presented with abdominal pain and vomiting. On eliciting further history, it was found that she had a psychiatric illness. On examination, there was evidence of balding on one side of the head. The doctor advised a barium swallow examination which is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Bezoars are accumulations of indigestible substances within the gastrointestinal tract, often leading to complications such as small bowel obstruction.

  • Common Associations:
    • Previous Gastric Surgery: Patients with a history of gastric surgery are at increased risk.
    • Psychiatric Illness: Certain psychiatric conditions may contribute to the formation of bezoars.

Types of Bezoars

  1. Trichobezoar: Formed from hair. When the tail extends through the small bowel, it is referred to as Rapunzel syndrome.
  2. Phytobezoar: Composed of indigestible food materials (e.g., cellulose) and commonly seen in patients with impaired digestion or decreased gastric motility.

Bezoars can lead to small bowel obstruction, and imaging, particularly CT, may reveal the following features:

  • Mass Appearance: The bezoar may appear as a mass in the obstructed segment of the bowel.
  • Outlining Fluid: It may be surrounded by fluid in the proximally dilated small bowel.
  • Mottled Appearance: The mass may have a mottled appearance due to trapped air within it.

KEY TAKEAWAY - Bezoars can lead to small bowel obstruction on CT appear as a mass in the obstructed segment of the bowel.

questions.text: A patient presented with difficulty in swallowing. There was no complaint in swallowing liquid foods. On coughing some solid food used to come out. ON the basis of this findings the physician ordered a barium swallow examination. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Esophageal webs are thin mucosal membranes that cause constriction within the esophagus, often leading to narrowing of the lumen. While many patients remain asymptomatic and may discover the condition incidentally, severe cases can result in significant symptoms such as dysphagia and regurgitation of food.

Location

  • Cervical Esophagus: Esophageal webs are more commonly found in the cervical region, particularly near the cricopharyngeus muscle.
  • Characteristics:
    • Typically arise from the anterior wall of the esophagus.
    • They do not originate from the posterior wall but can be circumferential.

Fluoroscopy: Barium Swallow

  • Demonstration: Esophageal webs can often be visualized on high-volume barium swallow studies when the esophagus is fully distended.
  • "Jet Effect": A characteristic "jet effect" may be observed, where contrast material passes distal to the web, indicating the presence of the membrane.

KEY TAKEAWAY -

  • Esophageal webs are more commonly found in the cervical region.
  • Many patients remain asymptomatic and may discover the condition incidentally.
  • severe cases can result in significant symptoms such as dysphagia and regurgitation of food.
  • Barium image of zenker's diverticulum.

questions.text:
A patient presented with chest pain and cough. He was advised to undergo a CXR which is shown below.

What is the most likely finding obtained in the spleen if he undergoes a CT scan of the abdomen?
questions.solution:
Polysplenia syndrome, also known as left isomerism, is a congenital condition classified as a type of heterotaxy syndrome. It is characterized by the presence of multiple small spleens, or splenules, on the left side of the body, often without a single, dominant spleen. This condition can occur unilaterally (on the left side) or bilaterally.

Cardiovascular

  • Congenital Heart Disease: Affects more than 50% of patients, typically less severe and less complex than those seen in asplenia syndrome.
  • Abnormal Pulmonary Venous Return: Present in about 70% of cases, including:
    • Partial Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Return (PAPVR)
    • Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Return (TAPVR)
  • Dextrocardia: Observed in approximately 37% of patients.

Gastrointestinal

  • Pancreatic Abnormalities:
    • Semi-annular pancreas or dorsal pancreatic agenesis.
  • Midgut Malrotation: Seen in about 80% of patients.
  • Gallbladder Agenesis: Affects around 50% of cases, along with possible biliary atresia.
  • Mobile Cecum: Increased mobility of the cecum.
  • Tracheoesophageal Fistula: Possible presence.
  • Absent C-loop of Duodenum: Can occur.

Genitourinary

  • Renal Anomalies:
    • Renal cysts.
    • Renal agenesis.
    • Ovarian cysts.

Vascular

  • Inferior Vena Cava (IVC) Anomalies: Including:
    • Intrahepatic IVC interruption with azygos or hemiazygos continuation.
    • Portal vein anomalies, such as preduodenal portal vein.

KEY TAKEAWAY - Polysplenia syndrome, also known as left isomerism, is characterized by the presence of multiple small spleens, or splenules, on the left side of the body, often without a single, dominant spleen.

questions.text: A patient presented with difficulty in swallowing of food and weight loss since 2 months. The laboratorial tests revealed anemia and reduced WBC counts. He underwent a barium swallow which showed suspicious mucosal irregularity in the lower esophagus. Further CT scan was advised which is shown below. What is the most likely route of spread of this lesion?
questions.solution:
Gastrohepatic lymph nodes play a crucial role in the spread and prognosis of esophageal cancer. These nodes are located near the liver and stomach, and they can be a common site for cancer cells to spread.

Among the given options, the gastrohepatic lymph nodes is the correct answer.

KEY TAKEAWAY - The number and location of lymph nodes involved in esophageal cancer are important factors in determining the stage of the disease. This staging helps in planning the appropriate treatment.

questions.text:
A patient presented with blood in stools and weight loss. He had a family history of colorectal cancer in his father. On considering this history, a CT scan was advised which is shown below.
The image showed a heterogeneously enhancing lesion in the ascending colon which was suggestive of colon cancer. He underwent treatment and was free of cancer. He has a daughter. She is at risk of developing which of the following cancers?
questions.solution:
HNPCC is an autosomal dominant condition caused by mutations in DNA mismatch repair (MMR) genes, leading to a significantly increased risk of colorectal cancer

Extracolonic Malignancies: Besides colorectal cancer, individuals with Lynch syndrome have elevated risks for several other cancers:

  • Endometrial Cancer: often presenting before colorectal cancer.
  • Ovarian Cancer.
  • Genitourinary Tract Cancers
  • Small bowel cancer

questions.text: A patient presented with mucocutaneous pigmentation. His father had a similar history however no other clinical finding was seen. The physician was suspicious of a syndromic association. He underwent a CT scan which shows homogeneously enhancing lesions in the intestine. What is the finding in the gastrointestinal region expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Peutz-Jeghers Syndrome

  1. Genetic and Clinical Features:
    • Inheritance: Autosomal dominant condition.
    • Polyps: Characterized by multiple hamartomatous polyps, primarily affecting the small intestine (especially the jejunum), with involvement of the colon and stomach. The mouth and esophagus are typically spared.
    • Pigmentation: Mucocutaneous melanin pigmentation occurs, notably involving the lips, oral cavity, fingers, and toes.
  2. Polyp Characteristics:
    • Peutz-Jeghers polyps are non-neoplastic hamartomas that exhibit a distinctive tree-like branching pattern, with a smooth muscle core continuous with the muscularis mucosa.
  3. Cancer Risks:
    • GI Malignancies: Increased risks for gastrointestinal adenocarcinomas, though the polyps themselves are not premalignant.

KEY TAKEAWAY -

  • Peutz-Jeghers Syndrome Characterized by multiple hamartomatous polyps
  • They are non-neoplastic hamartomas that exhibit a distinctive tree-like branching pattern
  • Mucocutaneous melanin pigmentation occurs, notably involving the lips, oral cavity, fingers, and toes

questions.text: A patient had a history of diarrhea since 5 years. He also had chronic weight loss. The blood tests revealed anemia and increased calprotectin levels. Now he developed discharge from umbilicus. He was diagnosed with Crohn's disease with enterocutaneous fistula and underwent a barium enema. Which of the following signs can be seen in Crohn's disease?
questions.solution:
Crohn disease, or regional enteritis, is an idiopathic inflammatory bowel disease characterized by discontinuous inflammation throughout the gastrointestinal tract, most commonly affecting the terminal ileum and proximal colon.

  1. Fluoroscopy:
    • Barium Studies: Show mucosal ulcers, longitudinal fissures, cobblestone appearance, and "string sign" due to narrowing.
    • Other Features: Thickened bowel folds, pseudodiverticula, and widely separated loops due to creeping fat.
  2. Ultrasound:
    • Findings: Bowel wall thickening (>3-4 mm), non-compressible loops, loss of peristalsis, and increased vascularity. Complications like abscesses and fistulas can also be detected.
  3. CT Imaging:
    • Common Features: Mural hyperenhancement, bowel wall thickening (1-2 cm), comb sign (engorged vasa recta), and mesenteric fat stranding. Strictures and fistulas are frequently observed. Following image shown comb sign and target sign.
  4. MRI (MR Enterography):
    • Characteristics: Segmental mural hyperenhancement, stratified enhancement patterns, and signs of inflammation (e.g., engorged vasa recta). Strictures can be identified by upstream bowel dilatation.

Complications:

  • Fistulas and abscesses are common, often associated with strictures. Extraintestinal manifestations include hepatobiliary disease and sacroiliitis.

KEY TAKEAWAY-

  • string sign seen in Crohn's diseases in barium studies.
  • "Lead pipe sign" is a radiological finding observed on a barium enema or CT scan in patients with ulcerative colitis. It refers to a loss of haustral folds in the colon, giving it a smooth, tubular appearance resembling a lead pipe.

questions.text: A patient presented with chronic diarrhea and bloating. He underwent a colonoscopy which showed multiple ulcers in the colon. He was advised to undergo a CT enterography which is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ulcerative colitis (UC) is an inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) primarily affecting the colon and associated with various extra-intestinal manifestations.

CT Imaging showing: Mural stratification (target appearance), submucosal fat deposition (fat halo sign), and strictures common.

Associated with Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis

Extra-Intestinal Manifestations:

  • Uveitis, erythema nodosum, thrombotic complications, and seronegative spondyloarthropathy.
  • Rarely, hypertrophic osteoarthropathy and chronic active hepatitis.

Imaging Features:

  1. Plain Radiograph:
    • Non-specific; may show mural thickening and thumbprinting in severe cases.
  2. Fluoroscopy (Barium Enema):
    • Provides detailed visualization of mucosal inflammation, granular appearance, and undermined ulcers.
    • In chronic cases, may show loss of haustral markings (lead pipe sign) and pseudopolyps.
  3. CT Imaging:
    • Similar findings to barium studies, with the ability to visualize complications like perforation or abscesses.
    • Mural stratification (target appearance), submucosal fat deposition (fat halo sign), and strictures common.
    • Colorectal carcinoma typically appears sessile.
  4. MRI:
    • Useful for assessing disease severity with colonic wall thickening and increased enhancement.
    • Median wall thickness in UC ranges from 4.7 to 9.8 mm; >4 mm indicates pathology.

KEY TAKEAWAY- Extra-Intestinal manifestations of UC

  • Erythema nodosum: Red, tender bumps under the skin.
  • Pyoderma gangrenosum: Ulcers and sores that can be painful and difficult to heal.
  • Arthritis: Joint pain and swelling, often affecting the large joints.
  • Ankylosing spondylitis: Inflammation of the spine.
  • Uveitis: Inflammation of the middle layer of the eye.
  • Conjunctivitis: Inflammation of the conjunctiva, the thin, clear membrane that covers the white part of the eye and the inner surface of the eyelids.
  • Primary sclerosing cholangitis: Inflammation and scarring of the bile ducts.
  • Gallstones: Small, hard stones that form in the gallbladder.

questions.text: What is the investigation of choice of 5-year-old patient presenting to the emergency department with an acute onset of RIF pain?
questions.solution:
Acute appendicitis is characterized by the inflammation of the vermiform appendix, typically presenting with a classic symptomatology.

Clinical Presentation

  • Pain: Begins as referred periumbilical pain (T10) that migrates to McBurney's point in the right iliac fossa.

Imaging Modalities

  • Ultrasound: Preferred for young patients and women of child-bearing age due to the absence of ionizing radiation.

Ultrasound Findings Suggestive of Appendicitis

  1. Target (Bull's Eye) Sign: Indicates bowel wall thickening in the context of acute inflammation.
  2. Non-Compressible, Fluid-Filled Appendix: Appendiceal diameter >6 mm, where ultrasound measurements are typically 1-2 mm less than CT.
  • Appendicolith: Hyperechoic with posterior acoustic shadowing.

KEY TAKEAWAY - Ultrasound Preferred for young patients and women of child-bearing age due to the absence of ionizing radiation.

questions.text: A patient presented with acute onset of abdominal pain localized to right iliac fossa. On examination there was tenderness at McBurney's sign point. He underwent an USG investigation. Which of the following image matches the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Acute appendicitis is characterized by the inflammation of the vermiform appendix, typically presenting with a classic symptomatology.

Ultrasound Findings Suggestive of Appendicitis

  1. Target (Bull's Eye) Sign: Indicates bowel wall thickening in the context of acute inflammation.
  2. Non-Compressible, Fluid-Filled Appendix: Appendiceal diameter >6 mm, where ultrasound measurements are typically 1-2 mm less than CT.

Clinical Presentation

  • Pain: Begins as referred periumbilical pain (T10) that migrates to McBurney's point in the right iliac fossa.
  • If Score >7, the diagnosis is likely

Image showing Increased echogenicity of the pyramid and renal calculi in the right kidney: medullary nephrocalcinosis

KEY TAKEAWAY - Appendicitis pain begins as periumbilical pain (T10) that migrates to McBurney's point in the right iliac fossa.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis on the basis of given barium study?
questions.solution:
A hiatus hernia occurs when abdominal contents, most commonly the stomach, herniate through the esophageal hiatus of the diaphragm into the thoracic cavity. Many patients remain asymptomatic, and it is often an incidental finding.

Types of Hiatus Hernia

  1. Sliding Hiatus Hernia (>90% of cases)
    • The gastro-esophageal junction and part of the stomach slide up into the thorax.
  2. Rolling (Para-esophageal) Hiatus Hernia (<10% of cases)
    • Part of the stomach bulges through the diaphragm next to the esophagus, while the gastro-esophageal junction remains in place.

Imaging Modalities for Diagnosis

  1. Plain Radiograph
    • Findings:
      • Retrocardiac opacity with a gas-fluid level may indicate the presence of a hernia.
  2. Fluoroscopy
    • Findings:
      • Numerous coarse thick gastric folds within the suprahiatal pouch.
      • A tortuous esophagus with an eccentric gastro-esophageal junction.

KEY TAKEAWAY -

OTHER OPTIONS:

Option B: Carcinoma esophagus with rat tail appearance on barium studies

Option C: Benign Gastric ulcer showing hampton line on barium studies

Option D: CA colon showing apple core sign on barium studies.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Peptic ulcer disease includes various conditions characterized by mucosal ulceration due to the effects of gastric acid, primarily affecting the stomach and the duodenum.

Risk Factors

  1. Helicobacter pylori infection
  2. NSAID use
  3. Corticosteroids
  4. Severe physiological stress/illness (e.g., intensive care admissions)
  5. Zollinger-Ellison syndrome
  6. Hypercalcemia

KEY TAKEAWAY -

questions.text: A 60-year-old male who was having constipation for a long time presented to emergency department with complaints of abdominal fullness, vomiting and obstipation. X-Ray is shown below. What is most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Sigmoid volvulus is a condition where the sigmoid colon twists around its mesentery, leading to a large bowel obstruction.

Imaging Features

Abdominal Radiographs

  • Findings:
    1. Large, Dilated Loop of Colon: Often accompanied by several gas-fluid levels.
  • Specific Signs:
    1. Coffee Bean Sign: The dilated sigmoid colon appears as a coffee bean shape on the X-ray.
    2. Frimann-Dahl Sign: Three dense lines (RED ARROWS) converge toward the site of obstruction, indicating the twisted bowel.
    3. Absent Rectal Gas: A typical finding suggesting distal obstruction.

Water-Soluble Contrast Enema

  • Although less commonly performed now, this test can provide detailed imaging of the condition:
    • Beak Sign (or Bird Beak Sign): A characteristic narrowing at the site of the obstruction.
    • Large Gas-Filled Loop: Lacks haustra, indicating a closed-loop obstruction.
    • Whirl Sign: Twisting of the mesentery and mesenteric vessels, indicative of volvulus.

KEY TAKEAWAY- Sigmoid volvulus causes:

  • Weak colonic musculature: The sigmoid colon is naturally more prone to twisting due to its long, mobile nature.
  • Constipation: Chronic constipation can contribute to the development of sigmoid volvulus.
  • Neurological disorders: Conditions such as Parkinson's disease or spinal cord injury can weaken the colonic muscles.
  • Medications: Certain medications, such as narcotic pain relievers, can slow down bowel movements and increase the risk of volvulus.

questions.text: Below given X-Ray indicate obstruction of which of the bowel loops?
questions.solution:
Large bowel obstruction is a condition characterized by the inability to pass stool or gas due to a blockage in the large intestine. It presents with abdominal pain, distension, and failure to pass flatus or stool.

Common Causes of LBO

  1. Colorectal Carcinoma: Most common cause (50-60% of cases)
  2. Pelvic Tumors: Either direct spread or metastatic disease.
  3. Colonic Diverticulitis.
  4. Volvulus:
    • Cecal Volvulus: 1-3% of cases.
    • Cecal Bascule.
    • Sigmoid Volvulus: 3-8% of cases.
  5. Ischemic Stricture: Related to ischemic colitis.
  6. Fecal Impaction/Fecaloma: Common in debilitated elderly patients.

Imaging Findings

Plain Radiograph

  • Colonic Distension: Gaseous distension due to gas-producing organisms in feces.
  • Collapsed Distal Colon: Few or no air-fluid levels found in the large bowel due to reabsorption of water.
  • Small Bowel Dilatation: Depends on:
    • Duration of obstruction.
    • Incompetence of the ileocecal valve.
  • Rectal Air: Little or no air present in the rectum.
  • Green arrows = dilated small bowel loops.
  • Red arrows = dilated large bowel loops.
    • Note how the sigmoid colon has a relatively abrupt cut-off at the level of the femoral head.
  • Blue arrows = absent rectal gas.

KEY TAKEAWAY - large bowel obstruction - The affected segment of the large intestine will appear enlarged and distended.

Lack of haustral markings: The normal folds or pouches within the large intestine (haustral markings) will be absent or diminished.

Gas-filled loops: The dilated loops will be filled with gas, creating a "gas-filled sausage" appearance.
